questions.question: A company sells products with a 30-day return policy. At the time of sale, the company should recognize:

options.A: Full revenue with no adjustment for returns
options.B: Revenue net of estimated returns, with a refund liability and asset for expected returned goods
options.C: No revenue until the return period expires

questions.explanation: When products are sold with a right of return, recognize revenue for amount expected to be entitled (net of returns), a refund liability for expected refunds, and an asset for the right to recover products from customers.
questions.tip: Returns: Revenue = expected to keep. Refund liability + recovery asset for returns. Update estimates each period.

questions.question: A company offers customers a coupon for 40% off their next purchase. This coupon represents:

options.A: A marketing expense with no revenue impact
options.B: A material right that is a separate performance obligation

questions.explanation: A customer option (discount, coupon) is a separate performance obligation if it provides a material right the customer wouldn't receive without entering into the contract. Allocate transaction price between the sale and the option.
questions.tip: Material right = significant discount customer wouldn't otherwise get. Treat as separate performance obligation.

questions.question: A retailer has goods available at cost of $60,000 and at retail of $100,000. Net sales were $70,000. Using the retail method, estimated ending inventory at cost is:
questions.explanation: Cost ratio = $60,000 / $100,000 = 60%. Ending inventory at retail = $100,000 - $70,000 = $30,000. Ending inventory at cost = $30,000 × 60% = $18,000.
questions.tip: Retail method: Cost ratio = Cost / Retail. Apply to ending inventory at retail to get cost.

questions.question: A company has a non-cancelable commitment to purchase inventory at $50,000. Current market value is $40,000. The company should:

options.B: Record a $10,000 loss and liability

questions.explanation: When market value falls below committed purchase price on a non-cancelable commitment, recognize a loss and liability immediately. This is similar to lower of cost or market treatment.
questions.tip: Purchase commitment loss: If market < committed price, accrue loss now. Don't wait for delivery.

questions.question: Interest is capitalized during construction based on:

options.A: All interest expense for the period
options.B: The avoidable interest that could have been avoided if construction expenditures had not been made

questions.explanation: Avoidable interest is the amount that theoretically could have been avoided if the asset construction expenditures had not been made. It's computed by applying interest rates to weighted-average accumulated expenditures.
questions.tip: Capitalize: Lesser of actual interest or avoidable interest. Avoidable = what could be avoided without the project.

questions.question: In an exchange lacking commercial substance, the party receiving cash boot recognizes gain to the extent of:

options.B: A proportionate amount based on boot received to total consideration
options.C: No gain until the new asset is sold
options.D: The fair value of boot received

questions.explanation: When an exchange lacks commercial substance but boot is received, recognize gain proportionately: (Boot received / Total consideration) × Total gain. The remainder is deferred by reducing the new asset's basis.
questions.tip: Boot received = recognize proportionate gain. Boot paid = no gain recognized. Applies when no commercial substance.

questions.question: Costs of developing software to be sold are capitalized beginning when:

options.A: The project is approved by management
options.B: Technological feasibility has been established

questions.explanation: For software to be sold/licensed, capitalize costs after technological feasibility is established (completion of detailed program design or working model). Before that point, expense as R&D. Capitalize until product is ready for release.
questions.tip: Software for sale: Expense until tech feasibility, capitalize until ready for release, then amortize.

questions.question: Costs incurred during the application and infrastructure development stage of a website should be:

options.B: Capitalized as intangible assets

questions.explanation: Website development has three stages: (1) Planning - expense, (2) Application/infrastructure development - capitalize, (3) Operating - generally expense (maintenance). Similar to internal-use software guidance.
questions.tip: Website costs: Planning = expense. Development = capitalize. Operating/maintenance = expense.

questions.question: An investor pays more than book value for an equity method investment due to undervalued equipment. The excess should be:

options.B: Amortized as an adjustment to equity income over the equipment's remaining life
options.C: Left unadjusted until investment is sold
options.D: Recorded as goodwill on the investor's books

questions.explanation: Excess cost over book value must be allocated to specific assets/liabilities (like in a business combination). The portion allocated to depreciable assets reduces equity income over the asset's remaining life.
questions.tip: Equity method basis differences: Allocate like acquisition, amortize over remaining lives. Reduces equity income.

questions.question: A company elects the fair value option for an equity method investment. Changes in fair value are reported:

options.B: In net income

questions.explanation: The fair value option allows companies to measure eligible financial instruments at fair value with changes in fair value recognized in earnings. Once elected, it's generally irrevocable.
questions.tip: Fair value option: Irrevocable election, changes through earnings. Alternative to equity method or amortized cost.

questions.question: Initial direct costs incurred by a lessee in an operating lease are:

options.B: Added to the right-of-use asset and amortized over the lease term
options.C: Recorded as a separate intangible asset

questions.explanation: Lessee initial direct costs are added to the right-of-use asset for both finance and operating leases. They are then amortized (for finance leases) or included in straight-line lease expense (operating leases).
questions.tip: Lessee IDC: Add to ROU asset. Lessor: Depends on lease type (sales-type = expense, direct financing = defer).

questions.question: A lessee may elect to not recognize a lease liability and ROU asset for leases with a term of:

options.B: 12 months or less with no purchase option reasonably certain to be exercised

questions.explanation: The short-term lease exemption applies to leases of 12 months or less at commencement (including renewal options reasonably certain to be exercised) with no purchase option reasonably certain to be exercised.
questions.tip: Short-term lease: ≤12 months + no purchase option likely. Can expense straight-line instead of recognizing ROU/liability.

questions.question: Debt issuance costs are presented on the balance sheet as:

options.B: A direct deduction from the carrying amount of the debt

questions.explanation: Under ASU 2015-03, debt issuance costs are presented as a direct deduction from the debt liability (similar to debt discount). They are amortized to interest expense using the effective interest method.
questions.tip: Debt issuance costs: Deduct from debt on balance sheet. Amortize to interest expense over debt term.

questions.question: Under ASC 420, a liability for one-time employee termination benefits should be recognized when:

options.B: The plan is communicated to employees and they are not required to render future service
options.D: The restructuring is announced to shareholders

questions.explanation: One-time termination benefits are recognized when: (1) management commits to a plan, (2) the plan identifies employees, activities, timing, and benefits, (3) actions to complete plan make significant changes unlikely, (4) plan is communicated.
questions.tip: Restructuring liability: Recognize when communicated and no future service required. Not just when planned.

questions.question: An employer must accrue a liability for employees' rights to receive compensation for future absences when the obligation is attributable to services already rendered, rights vest or accumulate, payment is probable, and:

options.A: Employees have requested the time off
options.B: The amount can be reasonably estimated

questions.explanation: Compensated absences (vacation, sick pay) are accrued if: (1) attributable to past services, (2) rights vest or accumulate, (3) payment is probable, (4) amount is reasonably estimable. All four criteria required.
questions.tip: Vacation accrual: Past service + vest/accumulate + probable + estimable. Sick pay often not accrued (no vest).

questions.question: When stock rights are issued to existing shareholders, the issuing company should:

options.B: Make only a memo entry unless the rights are exercised

questions.explanation: Stock rights issued to existing shareholders (preemptive rights) require only a memo entry. No journal entry until exercised. This differs from stock options granted to employees (compensation expense).
questions.tip: Stock rights to shareholders: Memo entry only. When exercised: Dr. Cash, Cr. Stock + APIC.

questions.question: A company appropriates retained earnings for plant expansion. This appropriation:

options.A: Sets aside cash for the expansion
options.B: Restricts dividends but doesn't affect total stockholders' equity
options.D: Creates a liability for future expansion

questions.explanation: Retained earnings appropriations are internal reclassifications that restrict dividend availability. They don't set aside cash or change total equity—just move amounts from unappropriated to appropriated retained earnings.
questions.tip: Appropriations: Restrict dividends, don't set aside cash. Total equity unchanged. Usually reversed when purpose fulfilled.

questions.question: Under CARES Act provisions (2020), NOLs arising in 2018-2020 could be carried back:

options.B: 5 years

questions.explanation: The CARES Act temporarily allowed 5-year carrybacks for NOLs arising in 2018, 2019, and 2020. This was an exception to TCJA's general elimination of carrybacks. Post-2020 NOLs generally cannot be carried back.
questions.tip: NOL rules change frequently. TCJA: No carryback, 80% limit. CARES: 5-year carryback for 2018-2020 losses.

questions.question: Investment tax credits can be accounted for using the flow-through method or:

options.B: The deferral method (reduce asset basis or defer credit)

questions.explanation: Investment tax credits can be recognized using: (1) Flow-through - reduce tax expense immediately, or (2) Deferral - reduce asset cost (or defer and amortize credit) over asset life. Both methods are acceptable.
questions.tip: ITC methods: Flow-through (immediate benefit) or Deferral (spread over asset life). Policy choice.

questions.question: Proprietary funds use which measurement focus and basis of accounting?

options.A: Current financial resources and modified accrual
options.B: Economic resources and accrual

questions.explanation: Proprietary funds (enterprise and internal service) use economic resources measurement focus and full accrual basis—like commercial businesses. Governmental funds use current financial resources and modified accrual.
questions.tip: Proprietary funds = business-like accounting (full accrual). Governmental funds = modified accrual.

questions.question: An interfund transfer from the general fund to an enterprise fund is reported as:

options.B: Other financing use in general fund, transfer in for enterprise fund

questions.explanation: Interfund transfers are reported as 'other financing sources/uses' in governmental funds and as 'transfers in/out' in proprietary funds. They are not revenues or expenses—they're non-exchange internal movements.
questions.tip: Interfund transfers: Not revenue/expense. 'Other financing source/use' in governmental, 'transfers' in proprietary.

questions.question: Government-wide financial statements present governmental activities and business-type activities using:

options.B: Net position categories (net investment in capital assets, restricted, unrestricted)

questions.explanation: Government-wide statements report net position in three categories: (1) Net investment in capital assets, (2) Restricted (by external constraints), (3) Unrestricted. This differs from governmental fund balance classifications.
questions.tip: Government-wide: Net position categories. Fund statements: Fund balance classifications (nonspendable through unassigned).

questions.question: Net assets designated by the board for a specific purpose are classified as:

options.B: Net assets without donor restrictions

questions.explanation: Board designations are internal management decisions, not external restrictions. Board-designated amounts remain in 'net assets without donor restrictions' but may be disclosed separately. Only donors can create restrictions.
questions.tip: Board designation ≠ donor restriction. Board-designated stays in 'without restrictions.' Disclose separately if material.

questions.question: An endowment fund's fair value falls below the original gift amount. Under UPMIFA, the deficiency is reported:

options.B: Within net assets with donor restrictions
options.C: As a loss in unrestricted net assets

questions.explanation: Underwater endowments (FV < original gift) are reported within net assets with donor restrictions. The original amount classification doesn't change. UPMIFA allows spending from underwater endowments if prudent.
questions.tip: Underwater endowment: Keep in 'with donor restrictions.' Disclose aggregate underwater amounts and original gift values.

questions.question: Under the indirect method, an increase in accounts payable is:

options.B: Added to net income

questions.explanation: An increase in AP means cash wasn't paid for some expenses that reduced net income. Add back to convert accrual income to cash basis. Increases in current liabilities = add; increases in current assets = subtract.
questions.tip: Indirect method: +Δ liabilities, −Δ assets. AP increased = bought on credit = add back (less cash used).

questions.question: Equipment with original cost of $100,000 and accumulated depreciation of $70,000 was sold for $40,000. The cash flow statement shows investing inflow of:
questions.explanation: Cash flow statement reports actual cash received ($40,000) as an investing inflow. The gain ($40,000 - $30,000 book value = $10,000) is removed from operating activities under indirect method to avoid double-counting.
questions.tip: Investing section: Report actual cash received. Remove gain from operating (indirect) to avoid counting twice.

questions.question: During the measurement period (up to one year), adjustments to provisional amounts recorded in a business combination are:

options.A: Recognized prospectively as adjustments to current period earnings
options.B: Recorded as if known at acquisition date, with retrospective adjustment
options.C: Not permitted once the acquisition is recorded

questions.explanation: Measurement period adjustments to provisional amounts are recorded as if known at acquisition date. Prior period financial statements are adjusted if comparative statements are presented. Period ends at 1 year or when information obtained.
questions.tip: Measurement period: Adjust as if known at acquisition date. Retrospective. Max 1 year.

questions.question: In-process research and development acquired in a business combination is:

options.B: Capitalized as an indefinite-lived intangible until project completion or abandonment

questions.explanation: Acquired IPR&D is recognized as an indefinite-lived intangible, tested for impairment until the project is completed (then amortize) or abandoned (then write off). Not expensed immediately like internal R&D.
questions.tip: Acquired IPR&D: Capitalize as indefinite-lived. Complete → amortize. Abandon → write off. Different from internal R&D.

questions.question: When a foreign subsidiary operates in a highly inflationary economy (cumulative inflation >100% over 3 years), its functional currency is deemed to be:

options.B: The reporting currency of the parent

questions.explanation: In highly inflationary economies, the parent's reporting currency becomes the subsidiary's functional currency. Use remeasurement (temporal method) instead of translation. Gains/losses go to income, not OCI.
questions.tip: Highly inflationary: Use parent's currency as functional. Remeasure (temporal method), gains/losses to income.

questions.question: Gains and losses on a hedge of a net investment in a foreign operation are reported in:

options.B: The cumulative translation adjustment in OCI
options.D: As an adjustment to the investment balance

questions.explanation: Net investment hedges protect against translation exposure. Effective portions of gains/losses go to OCI (cumulative translation adjustment), offsetting translation gains/losses on the foreign operation.
questions.tip: Net investment hedge: Effective portion → CTA (OCI). Offsets translation gains/losses on foreign subsidiary.

questions.question: Stock options are excluded from diluted EPS calculation when:

options.A: They have been outstanding for less than one year
options.B: The exercise price exceeds the average market price (antidilutive)
options.C: The company has a net loss

questions.explanation: Options are antidilutive when exercise price > market price (treasury stock method produces no incremental shares). Also, in a loss year, all potentially dilutive securities are antidilutive because they would reduce the loss per share.
questions.tip: Antidilutive: Exercise price > market price, OR net loss year. Exclude from diluted EPS.

questions.question: Shares contingently issuable upon meeting certain earnings targets are included in diluted EPS when:

options.B: The contingency conditions are currently satisfied
options.C: Management expects conditions will be met

questions.explanation: Contingently issuable shares are included in diluted EPS if the contingency conditions would be satisfied based on current period results (as if period-end were the end of the contingency period).
questions.tip: Contingent shares: Include in diluted EPS if conditions met now. Based on current results, not future expectations.

questions.question: Under ASU 2017-07, service cost for defined benefit pension plans is reported:

options.A: With other pension components below operating income
options.B: In operating expenses with compensation costs

questions.explanation: ASU 2017-07 requires service cost to be presented with other employee compensation costs (operating). Other components (interest, expected return, amortization) are presented outside operating income or disclosed separately.
questions.tip: Pension expense split: Service cost = operating. All other components = non-operating (or disclose separately).

questions.question: A pension settlement (lump-sum payment to plan participants) triggers recognition of:

options.B: A proportionate amount of unrecognized gains/losses and prior service cost

questions.explanation: A settlement triggers immediate recognition of a proportionate share of unrecognized gains/losses and prior service cost in AOCI. The proportion is based on the percentage of PBO settled.
questions.tip: Settlement: Recognize proportionate share of AOCI items immediately. Triggered when significant PBO portion is settled.

questions.question: When a stock option's terms are modified to increase the fair value, the company recognizes:

options.A: The difference in fair value as a reduction of expense
options.B: The incremental fair value as additional compensation cost
options.D: A liability for the increased value

questions.explanation: Modifications resulting in increased fair value: Recognize incremental compensation cost (new FV minus old FV at modification date). Continue recognizing original cost plus the increment over remaining vesting period.
questions.tip: Stock comp modification: Incremental value = additional expense. If value decreases, keep original expense (no reduction).
